uk.ac.ebi.mdk.domain.entity.reaction
Class AbstractReaction<P extends Participant>

java.lang.Object
  uk.ac.ebi.mdk.domain.entity.AbstractEntity
      uk.ac.ebi.mdk.domain.entity.AbstractAnnotatedEntity
          uk.ac.ebi.mdk.domain.entity.reaction.AbstractReaction<P>
Type Parameters:
P - Reaction participant type
All Implemented Interfaces:
Externalizable, Serializable, Cloneable, AnnotatedEntity, Entity, Reaction<P>
Direct Known Subclasses:
IdentifierReactionImplementation, InChIReaction, MetabolicReactionImpl
public class AbstractReaction<P extends Participant>
extends AbstractAnnotatedEntity
implements Reaction<P>

AbstractReaction â€“ 2011.08.08

A base reaction class that allows the specification of different types of participant. Two important participant types are Participant and CompartmentalisedParticipant. Due to the verboseness of the later when provided with the three parameter types like MetabolicParticipant are usable.

Reaction<Participant<String,Integer>> rxn = new AbstractReaction<Participant<String,Integer>>();

rxn.addReactant(new ParticipantImplementation<String, Integer>("NAD+", 1));
rxn.addReactant(new ParticipantImplementation<String, Integer>("primary-alcohol", 1));

rxn.addProduct(new ParticipantImplementation<String, Integer>("NADH", 1));
rxn.addProduct(new ParticipantImplementation<String, Integer>("H+", 1));
rxn.addProduct(new ParticipantImplementation<String, Integer>("aldehyde", 1));


If you intend to use this library's Metabolite and Compartment implementations please use the concrete class MetabolicReaction.

Version:
$Rev$ : Last Changed $Date$
Author:
johnmay, $Author$ (this version)

Constructor Detail

AbstractReaction

public AbstractReaction()
Constructor for a generic reaction. The constructor must provide a comparator for class of molecule used in the generic reaction. Ideally this should be a singleton class.

Constructor to build a reaction and use the provided filter to trim down included molecules. Note â€“ the reaction doesn't need a new instance of the filter every-time and it is better to provide all required reactions with the same filter

Method Detail

setDirection

public void setDirection(Direction direction)
Sets the reversibility of the reaction. By default the reaction reversibility is unknown. The reversibility is not tested in the equals(M method as this method treats reactions with same products (coefficients and compartments), different sides as being the same.

Specified by:

hashCode

public int hashCode()
Calculates the hash code for the reaction in it's current state. As the molecules need to be sorted this operation is more expensive and thus non-optimal. The hash is therefore cached in a the variable this.cachedHash which is 'nullified' if the state of the object changes. Warning: This hash code will not persist between different virtual machines if enumerations are used. However as the hash code is meant to be calculated when needed this should not be a problem

Overrides:
hashCode in class AbstractAnnotatedEntity
Returns:
hash code the reaction, note â€“ there is no guarantee of unique hash code and the equals method should be called if the the matching hashCodes are found

equals

public boolean equals(Object obj)
Check equality of reactions based on state. Reactions are considered equals if their reactants and products (coefficients and compartments) are equals regardless of the side they reside on. For example A + B <-> C + D is considered equals to C + D <-> A + B. The participant stoichiometric coefficients and compartments are also checked.

To accomplish this the reactionParticipants and copied, sorted and then a hash for each side (four total) is made. Duplicate hashes are then removed via the interface and the query (this) and the other (obj) sides are tested for coefficient, compartment and finally molecule similarity

Overrides:
equals in class AbstractAnnotatedEntity
Parameters:
obj - The other object to test equality with
Returns:
Whether the objects are considered equals

toString

public String toString()
Displays the objects stored in the reaction in string form prefixed with the stoichiometric coefficients and post fixed with compartments if either exists. The reaction reversibility is determined by the enumeration value Reversibility enumeration. Example representation: (1)A [e] + (1)B [c] <=?=> (1)C [c] + (1)A [c] *

Overrides:
toString in class AbstractEntity
Returns:
textual representation of the reaction
